title: 103_s1661
content: The "Worker Protection Warnings Act of 1993" is referenced in the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970. The Congress recognizes the need for uniform warnings on personal protective equipment for occupational use to prevent confusion among employers and employees, reduce workplace injuries and illnesses, and address inconsistencies in state requirements. The Congress recognizes the need for uniform warnings on personal protective equipment for occupational use to prevent confusion among employers and employees, reduce workplace injuries and illnesses, and address inconsistencies in state requirements. Questions arise regarding the adequacy of warnings due to varying State regulations, prohibitions, and court decisions, creating challenges for interstate commerce in such equipment. The purpose of this Act is to enhance workplace safety by clarifying the proper use of personal protective equipment through uniform warnings. It also aims to preempt any conflicting state standards on the adequacy of these warnings. SEC. 5. UNIFORM WARNINGS FOR PERSONAL PROTECTIVE EQUIPMENT FOR OCCUPATIONAL USE. Section 6 (29 U.S.C. 655) is amended to include a new subsection requiring the Secretary, in consultation with the National Institute of Occupational Safety and Health, to establish uniform warnings for personal protective equipment within 12 months. Personal protective equipment refers to gear used by workers to protect various body parts in the workplace. The new subsection in Section 6 requires the Secretary to establish uniform warnings for personal protective equipment within 12 months. Personal protective equipment is gear used by workers to protect body parts in the workplace. The term 'warning' directs actions or procedures related to the use of personal protective equipment. Each standard issued for personal protective equipment must include uniform warnings within 12 months. These warnings outline actions or procedures related to the equipment's use and must be communicated to employers by manufacturers or sellers. Failure to comply may result in personal injury or death. Each standard for personal protective equipment must include warnings communicated to employees and training on proper use, application in the workplace, and consequences of non-compliance. The standard for personal protective equipment includes warnings for employees, training on proper use, workplace application, and consequences of non-compliance. The standard becomes effective 6 months after publication in the Federal Register and exempts warnings for equipment placed in interstate commerce before the effective date unless communicated to the employer as required. The Secretary considers various factors and expert opinions when promulgating standards for equipment warnings, including manufacturer experience, means of communication, worker opinions, human factors experts, and input from organizations like the National Institute of Occupational Safety and Health. The Secretary considers various factors and expert opinions, including means of communication, when promulgating standards for equipment warnings. SEC. 6. PREEMPTION. Section 4 and Section 18 of the Occupational Safety and Health Act are amended to clarify that Congress intends to regulate warnings for personal protective equipment and prevent states from establishing conflicting standards. The Occupational Safety and Health Act prohibits states from establishing conflicting standards for personal protective equipment, ensuring consistency with federal regulations.
